author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in Italy: A Converted 13th-Century Church Outside Milan
description: The Italian fashion center has been trying on a new look, with sleek developments rising fast among the city’s historic buildings.
content: This four-bedroom brick home is in the village of Morimondo, about 20 miles southwest of central Milan, in Italy’s Lombardy region. A former church that dates to the 13th century, the structure was converted to a 4,843-square-foot residence in 1980, said Diletta Giorgolo, head of residential for Italy Sotheby’s International Realty, which has the listing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Cherokee Nation Can Gather Sacred Plants on National Park Land
description: Five decades after the park service took over the Buffalo National River in Arkansas, the Cherokee can once again gather plants there to create medicine, food and supplies.
content: For generations, the Cherokee had gathered plants along the Buffalo River in Arkansas. The flora could be used to make a wide variety of things: blow guns, baskets, medicine and even ganatsi, a hickory nut soup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Debates Limits of Ruling for Tribes in Oklahoma
description: The argument was Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s last, and Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. ended it with a fond tribute to his colleague.
content: WASHINGTON — At the last argument of the Supreme Court’s current term, featuring what was very likely Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s last appearance on its bench, the justices on Wednesday considered the aftermath of a decision in 2020 declaring that much of eastern Oklahoma falls within Indian reservations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: All Enchiladas Are Perfect. But These Are My Favorite.
description: I found comfort in sizzling cheese, bubbling chili gravy and a new community.
content: Enchiladas are warm hugs, enveloped in tortillas and blanketed in sauce. Whether topped with hills of Cotija cheese, or a silky salsa verde, or handfuls of herbs, the dish is a shorthand for deliciousness. Even the name alone — enchiladas! — becomes a catalyst for anticipation: Comfort is in the vicinity. It’s on the way! Everything (or at least the next 15 minutes) could very well turn out fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Mohn
title: Canvases, Clay and Cameras, Preserving the Spirit of Ukraine
description: Ukrainian museums and institutions across the United States are presenting myriad exhibitions, some dealing with the war and others celebrating culture.
content: Nikita Kravtsov, a Ukrainian artist born in Crimea and now based in Paris, recently traveled to New York, where he completed nine brightly painted works on paper. A 1909 publication of “The War of the Mushrooms,” illustrated by the prominent Ukrainian graphic artist Heorhii Narbut, inspired Mr. Kravtsov’s new creations, which reimagine that classic Slavic fairy tale of good and evil through scenes of Russia’s current war with Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Is There a Ceiling on Internet Users?
description: There’s currently a limit to how many people in the world can use digital services like Facebook and Netflix.
content: Facebook and Netflix are finding it tough to recruit new people who want what they are offering. At least for now, their numbers of users are shrinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: China Continues to Fall Short of Promises to Protect Intellectual Property, U.S. Says
description: American officials said that they were monitoring China’s progress in meeting the terms of a 2020 trade deal, but that intellectual property owners had expressed concerns.
content: WASHINGTON — The Office of the United States Trade Representative criticized China, Russia and other countries on Wednesday for continuing to fall short of promises to protect intellectual property in a report that cataloged various infringements by America’s trading partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Composers Give New Shape to Ornette Coleman’s Jazz
description: A group of artists are reimagining the 1959 album “The Shape of Jazz to Come” for Bang on a Can’s Long Play festival.
content: Bang on a Can had big plans for 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Letter to Yankees Detailed Former Sign Stealing Scheme
description: A 2017 letter from Commissioner Rob Manfred confirmed the Yankees’ illicit use of electronic devices in 2015 and parts of 2016, which cost the team a $100,000 fine.
content: Sign stealing has long been a part of baseball strategy. When a batter is hitting, his teammates carefully watch a catcher’s fingers or body language to figure out what pitch is about to be thrown. That is all fair play as long as teams do not use any electronic devices, such as cameras or computers, to facilitate the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Seeking Another Reset, the N.C.A.A. Returns to the ‘Help Wanted’ Route
description: The N.C.A.A. is looking for a new president. Private jet notwithstanding, it’s not all that great of a gig.
content: It is difficult to trace when, exactly, Mark Emmert’s tenure as the N.C.A.A. president went from skidding to stalled, as the governing body of big-time college sports descended from juggernaut to supplicant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Carnegie Hall Will Return At Full Scale This Fall
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 27, 2022.
content: “It’s really, really important that a dictator does not win. We felt we needed to very overtly support Ukraine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Is Elon Musk About to Be the ‘King of Nothing’?
description: The billionaire’s $44 billion deal to buy Twitter and what comes next.
content: It happened: Elon Musk struck a deal to buy Twitter for $44 billion. The billionaire, who is one of the platform’s most popular users, has already hinted at some of the changes he aspires to “unlock” at the company, from making Twitter a platform for “free speech” to making its algorithms open source and purging spam bots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Hisako Ueno and Makiko Inoue
title: At 119, She Was a Symbol of How to Live With Wit and Vitality
description: Kane Tanaka, who died in Japan this month, survived two world wars, the 1918 influenza outbreak, paratyphoid and two rounds of cancer. She loved chocolate and hated losing at board games.
content: In September 2019, the mayor of Fukuoka, Japan, made a pilgrimage to see Kane Tanaka at her nursing home. She was 116 years old then and fielded questions from a gaggle of reporters with the cocky confidence of a prizefighter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Singapore Executes Drug Smuggler Despite Concerns Over Mental Disability
description: Defense lawyers had argued that the Malaysian man should not be executed because he was not fully capable of understanding his actions and had been coerced.
content: A Malaysian man convicted of smuggling drugs into Singapore was executed Wednesday despite appeals from human rights advocates and global business leaders who said he should be spared because he suffered from a mental disability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Blum
title: A Scrappier Model for Netflix Might Be More Sustainable
description: There’s one surefire way of controlling costs while increasing quality.
content: In the minutes after Netflix reported its quarterly earnings last week, the entire entertainment business had questions. Was that stock sell-off really happening? What did it mean for the industry’s pivot to streaming? And, of course, because this is Hollywood: Who was to blame?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: At Madeleine Albright’s Service, a Reminder of the Fight for Freedom
description: The former secretary of state, who died last month, was honored at Washington National Cathedral as America faces the kind of struggle between democracy and autocracy that she warned about.
content: WASHINGTON — She arrived on a ship called the SS America, an 11-year-old refugee fleeing tyranny for freedom. Nearly three-quarters of a century later, her adopted country bade farewell on Wednesday to Madeleine Korbel Albright, who in the course of a storybook life became a relentless evangelist for American ideals at home and abroad and an implacable foe of tyranny everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Where Does All That Hate We Feel Come From?
description: New research in psychology and political science reveals just how deep our anxieties about others lie.
content: “The story of the 21st century is less a story about exponential population growth than it is a story about differential growth — marked by a stark divide between the world’s richest and poorest countries,” Jennifer Sciubba, a professor of international studies at Rhodes College, writes in her new book, “8 Billion and Counting: How Sex, Death and Migration Shape Our World.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Gould
title: More Kids? After the Last Two Years? No Thanks.
description: The travails of pandemic parenting have been well documented. But how has this time shaped decision-making (and baby-making) going forward?
content: Two children had always been the plan for Anna Carey, and in early 2020 she was getting ready to start trying to conceive. Her daughter had just turned 2, and she and her husband were living happily, albeit far from family, in Toronto, where Ms. Carey had a part-time job at a marketing firm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Sofía Villamil
title: Colombian General and 10 Others Admit to Crimes Against Humanity
description: In the first hearing of its kind, officials admitted to orchestrating extrajudicial killings. But victims asked for more. “We know that there are powerful people behind you,” said one woman. “We need names.”
content: It was a moment many Colombians thought they would never see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Lananh Nguyen
title: Archegos stock manipulation scheme was ‘historic,’ U.S. attorney says.
description: Manhattan federal prosecutors arrested and criminally charged the owner, Bill Hwang, and his former top lieutenant in one of the highest-profile Wall Street prosecutions in years.
content: The sudden and stunning collapse of the once-obscure private investment firm Archegos Capital Management sent shock waves through the stock market last year and left Wall Street banks with $10 billion in losses almost overnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: 11 Electrocuted When Religious Chariot Hits Transmission Wires in India
description: Two of the 11 killed were children, and more than a dozen people were hurt as they fell or jumped from the vehicle, which was being pulled by devotees at a Hindu religious festival in southern India.
content: MUMBAI — At least 11 people, including two children, were electrocuted to death when their vehicle snagged overhead transmission lines and burst into flames as they rode in a religious procession in southern India, according to Indian authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
title: Fears Are Mounting That Ukraine War Will Spill Across Borders
description: American and European officials say their concern is based in part on a growing conviction that the war will not end any time soon.
content: WASHINGTON — For nine weeks, President Biden and the Western allies have emphasized the need to keep the war for Ukraine inside Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Elon Musk Got Twitter Because He Gets Twitter
description: Elon Musk reveals what he wants Twitter to be by how he acts on it.
content: Can Elon Musk break Twitter? I hope so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: From King Cobras to Geckos, 20 Percent of Reptiles Risk Extinction
description: The first global analysis of its kind found that logging and farming are taking away reptile habitat at an unsustainable pace, exacerbating a worldwide decline in biodiversity.
content: About 20 percent of reptile species risk extinction, mainly because people are taking away their habitats for agriculture, urban development and logging, according to the first global reptile assessment of its kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: Can Probiotics Boost Vaginal Health?
description: Pills and suppositories that promise to balance the vaginal microbiome are lining drugstore shelves and online marketplaces. But are they backed by science?
content: Before there were vaginal probiotics, there was the yogurt douche. In the 1970s, a common home remedy for yeast infections and other irritating ailments was to soak a tampon in plain, unsweetened yogurt and insert it into the vagina. The same live bacteria that make yogurt beneficial for the gut, the thinking went, might also be good for the vagina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Sarah Silverman’s Family Show (Really!) About Divorce and Depression
description: “Everything’s couched with hard jokes, but it’s also vulnerable,” the comic said of “The Bedwetter,” her new musical comedy.
content: When the comedian Sarah Silverman was maybe 8, her father gave her a joke book. This was no childhood compendium of riddles and rhymes. It was a collection of “tasteless” humor, and on the very first page, she recalled, it contained a zinger about Little Red Riding Hood getting it on with the Big Bad Wolf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Alejandro Cegarra
title: A Woman’s Haunting Disappearance Sparks Outrage in Mexico Over Gender Violence
description: The case of Debanhi Escobar, 18, in Monterrey has ignited a national outcry over the government’s failure to deliver justice for missing women.
content: MONTERREY, Mexico — On the 13th day of searching for his missing daughter, Mario Escobar stood outside a gas station in the choking heat, clutching fliers with her photo and the vestiges of a desperate, lingering hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rikki Novetsky, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rachelle Bonja, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Supreme Court Considers a Football Coach’s Prayers
description: The justices’ decision could have broad implications for freedom of religion — and freedom from it.
content: Joseph A. Kennedy, a former high school football coach, who lost his job after he made a habit of going to the 50-yard line after his team’s games to thank God and to lead his players in prayer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Democrats Ask if They Should Hit Back Harder Against the G.O.P.
description: Many of the party’s voters are hungry for their candidates to go on offense against Republican cultural attacks, even if it puts them on less comfortable political terrain.
content: If Democrats could bottle Mallory McMorrow, the Michigan state senator who gave a widely viewed speech condemning Republicans’ push to limit discussions about gender and sexuality in schools, they would do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert O'Connell
title: N.F.L. Draft Demands Well-Rounded Linemen Who Can Still Flatten
description: Ikem Ekwonu is expected to be the first of a group of agile, speedy offensive linemen drafted, the better to keep up with evolving playbooks and scampering quarterbacks.
content: Offensive linemen have always loved “pancakes” — no-doubt-about-it blocks that end with them flexing over flattened defenders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Where You Still Have to Wear a Mask in California
description: State officials have lifted mask mandates for most places, but not everywhere.
content: To mask or not to mask? That is the question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: Let’s Be Clear About What It’s Like to Be Harassed on Twitter
description: Free speech absolutism might backfire when it comes to increasing the company’s user base and profits.
content: The Tesla co-founder and chief executive Elon Musk is set to shortly become the new owner of a slightly used social media platform with more than 217 million daily users. He has said very little about how he plans to make the business work, but one thing is clear: He is really, really preoccupied with how we talk on the platform and appears intent on rolling back some of its moderation policies in order to allow all legal speech on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Trump Officials Awarded $700 Million Pandemic Loan Despite Objections
description: A congressional report raises new questions about a pandemic relief loan to a troubled trucking company with close ties to the Trump administration.
content: WASHINGTON — Democratic lawmakers on Wednesday released a report alleging that top Trump administration officials had awarded a $700 million pandemic relief loan to a struggling trucking company in 2020 over the objections of career officials at the Defense Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: In Dishes and Dolls, a Foundation of Feminist Art
description: A new show, “Women’s Work,” will illustrate how modern female artists have taken inspiration from domestic objects of past centuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: ‘A Black Lady Sketch Show’ Has the Most Exciting Comics (and the Silliest)
description: Robin Thede and her castmates bring a light, joyful touch and a comedy-nerd sensibility to this HBO series that often, delightfully, descends into the absurd.
content: In this Friday’s episode of “A Black Lady Sketch Show,” Robin Thede, its charismatic showrunner and star, plays the world’s worst thief. She picks fights with conspirators during a heist, wears a glittery silver wig that isn’t exactly inconspicuous, and, before stealing a diamond, takes a selfie and posts it to social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Britain broke the law by moving hospital patients to nursing homes early in the pandemic, a court rules.
description: The court’s ruling came in a lawsuit brought by two women whose fathers died in nursing homes in 2020.
content: The British government’s decision in the spring of 2020 to discharge hospital patients into nursing homes without testing them for the coronavirus was illegal, a British court ruled on Wednesday, weighing in on what has become a defining scandal for Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: European gas prices jump after Gazprom cuts natural gas to Poland and Bulgaria.
description: The market reaction underscored that a dreaded moment in the war had arrived: the severe disruption of Russian natural gas exports to the E.U.
content: BRUSSELS — Prices for natural gas futures in Europe jumped by more than 23 percent as trading began Wednesday morning, hours after Russia’s state-run Gazprom told Poland and Bulgaria it had cut supplies of the fuel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: How to Look at a Basquiat
description: It’s not every day that New York has two Basquiat exhibitions. At “Art and Objecthood,” decoding the basics: his materials, iconography and unmistakable line.
content: It’s not every day that New Yorkers can choose between two concurrent exhibitions of work by Jean-Michel Basquiat. “King Pleasure,” an immersive experience designed by the architect David Adjaye and curated by the artist’s sisters Lisane Basquiat and Jeanine Heriveaux, includes a recreation of Jean-Michel’s childhood bedroom and his studio and charges $35 admission. “Art and Objecthood,” curated by the art historian Dieter Buchhart at Nahmad Contemporary, gathers an extraordinary trove of paintings Basquiat made on doors, windows and a refrigerator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.9 Million Homes in Connecticut, Alabama and Washington
description: An 1846 country estate in Salisbury, a 1992 house in Mountain Brook and a three-bedroom retreat with water views in Bellingham.
content: This large property has numerous walking trails, and it is a few miles from Rand’s View on the Appalachian Trail, which offers hikers a panoramic look at the Berkshires landscape, especially beautiful in the spring and fall. The home is about a 15-minute drive from the center of Salisbury, with its antiques stores, bakeries and a general store selling locally made handicrafts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: ‘Manchinema’
description: Congress is back. Does President Biden’s agenda still have a chance?
content: Congress has returned to Washington after a recess, and Democrats are trying to come up with a slimmed-down version of President Biden’s domestic agenda that they can pass in coming weeks. If they succeed, they have the potential to slow climate change, reduce drug prices for millions of Americans and raise taxes on the wealthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Levere
title: After a Storied Career, a Nonagenarian Photographer Returns to New York
description: The International Center of Photography, now on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, recognizes William Klein, 94, by turning over its entire space to his work.
content: When the International Center of Photography hosts a retrospective of the work of William Klein this summer, it will be like a homecoming for the artist and a belated housewarming for the museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alina Tugend
title: Title IX at 50: How it Changed Congress, Campuses and Sports
description: The New-York Historical Society looks back on the landmark gender equality legislation and how it transformed women’s access to education, sports and more.
content: On this, the 50th anniversary of Title IX, the landmark gender equality legislation, Margaret Dunkle remembers thinking that the hard work was behind them once the law had passed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: The Mets Keep Getting Plunked and Are Looking for Answers
description: With 19 hit batsmen in 20 games, the Mets are concerned. Pitcher Chris Bassitt believes the baseballs are to blame.
content: With Mets batters being hit by pitches at a high rate this season, the team is running out of patience and looking for answers. At least one Mets player thinks there is a culprit: the baseballs Major League Baseball is using this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: The Unsettling Warning in France’s Election
description: A record number of abstentions, and a strictly binary choice for voters — many of whom said they were picking the lesser of two evils — are trouble signs even within a mature democracy.
content: You should know at least two crucial facts about the French presidential election, whose final round was held last Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: All the Andrew Wyeth No One Has Seen
description: A partnership between the artist’s foundation and two museums will enable much of his art to be viewed for the first time.
content: CHADDS FORD, Pa. — In Andrew Wyeth’s prolific career, which lasted seven decades, he worked largely within a small radius of his rural family homes here and in Cushing, Maine. Making acutely observed sketches of the landscapes and people in these isolated communities, he later translated them into paintings in the studio, creating indelible images of American life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: Art and Architecture Get a Refresh on the California Coast
description: The Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego has undergone multiple renovations in its 80-plus years. This spring it has opened after yet another.
content: SAN DIEGO — The Pacific Ocean surf steadily lapping at the coast not far from the newly renovated and expanded Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego serves as a metaphor for the successive waves of architecture that have formed the institution since it was founded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hanc
title: Welcome to Our City! Care to Visit the Museum?
description: In growing urban areas like Austin, Texas; Denver; and Raleigh, N.C., regional museums are rolling out the welcome mat.
content: RALEIGH, N.C. — In March 2020, Wilson Murphy decamped from Manhattan, where he had lived for more than 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Sturtz
title: Playing Against Type
description: Welcome to the world of competitive typing, where hands fly across keyboards — remember those? — and there’s nary an LOL in sight.
content: In the hands of Hunter Shaffer, the sentence you are reading right now would take seven or eight seconds to type. This entire article would be done in just over seven minutes, and a recent Sunday Styles print section of The New York Times would take about 86 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Aung San Suu Kyi Found Guilty in Myanmar Ahead of Biden Summit
description: The elected civilian leader, who was detained in a military coup last year, was sentenced to five years in prison in a corruption trial that was closed to the public.
content: A court sentenced Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, to five years in prison on Wednesday after finding her guilty of corruption for accepting about $1.3 million in gold bars and cash from a close political ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Survivor’ Review: Clenched Fists
description: In this drama from Barry Levinson, Ben Foster plays a Jewish boxer who, during the Holocaust, was forced to fight his fellow Jews for the Nazis’ entertainment.
content: No one is going to mistake “The Survivor” for Sidney Lumet’s “The Pawnbroker,” but this new film from Barry Levinson deals with the concept of Holocaust survivor’s guilt from a distinct and complicated perspective. The film concerns Harry Haft, a boxer who in 1949 lasted three rounds with a heavily favored Rocky Marciano. But of more note is how Haft, a Polish-born Jew, came to boxing. Years earlier, an S.S. officer who encountered Harry, born Hertzka, at Auschwitz-Birkenau enlisted him to pummel other Jews in bouts held for the entertainment of Nazi officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark A. Stein
title: A Defiant Exhibit by an Artist, at a Museum He Helped Create
description: El Museo del Barrio is presenting a retrospective of Raphael Montañez Ortiz’s works to honor the 88-year-old artist and reinforce the institution’s roots.
content: Raphael Montañez Ortiz was a celebrated avant-garde artist in 1969 when he helped a group of East Harlem parents, teachers and students create El Museo del Barrio, a museum that he said he believed would be more welcoming to Latin artists than New York’s established temples of fine art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Mystery of Marilyn Monroe: The Unheard Tapes’ Review: Gossip Girl
description: This documentary teases a vague conspiracy surrounding Monroe’s death — but mostly rehashes well-circulated facts and rumors.
content: If you call a movie “The Mystery of Marilyn Monroe: The Unheard Tapes,” your job is to provide at least something worth listening to. This documentary, directed by Emma Cooper in the latest addition to Netflix’s catalog of true-crime (or crime-ish) stories, begins by teasing some sort of conspiracy surrounding Marilyn Monroe’s 1962 death from an overdose. But mostly the film presents a banal rehash of established facts and well-circulated rumors about Monroe’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In a Gleeful ‘POTUS,’ White House Enablers Gone Wild
description: Seven female farceurs bring Selina Fillinger’s new Broadway comedy about the president’s protectors to life.
content: Keep your eye on the bust of Alice Paul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Will Elon Musk Save Twitter or Destroy It?
description: Musk says he wants to transform Twitter into “the platform for free speech around the globe.” The reality could look very different.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Cuts Gas Supplies
description: Also, Shanghai residents express anger and Singapore executes an intellectually disabled man.
content: In its toughest response yet to European sanctions, Russia halted natural gas shipments to Bulgaria and Poland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing posts a $1.5 billion loss and weaker revenue amid higher costs and delays.
description: Boeing reported a wider-than-expected loss and weaker revenue for the first quarter.
content: Boeing on Wednesday reported a wider loss and weaker revenue than analysts had expected for the first three months of the year amid higher costs and delays, including pushing back production of its next-generation twin-aisle plane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Beijing’s Testing Surge
description: And more than half of Americans have been infected by the virus.
content: Beijing is racing to test nearly all of its 22 million residents three times over five days in a high-stakes bid to avoid a similar fate as Shanghai, where millions of residents have been forced into an almost unbearable monthlong lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Lauren McCarthy
title: Officials watch and wonder as the hottest U.S. coronavirus hot spot swells to two dozen counties.
description: Health experts say that people in the hot spot, which includes cities like Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse, should be increasing their precautions.
content: The orange spot first appeared on the national risk map in early April, marking three counties in central New York as having “high” community levels of the coronavirus, the only such cluster in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: A Young Athlete Gets a Series of Infections. Why Wouldn’t They Go Away?
description: This 22-year-old was rarely sick until she suffered from several painful episodes.
content: The woman’s phone pinged, and she glanced down to see the message: “The bulge is bigger,” read the text, “and it hurts.” She hurried upstairs to her 22-year-old daughter’s room. On the young woman’s left hip was a patch of pink about the size of a golf ball. Just below her prominent hip bone where the skin should have dipped inward, it now bulged a little outward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Much Should Speech Be Moderated on Social Media?
description: Elon Musk pledged fewer limits to Twitter, which he is buying for $44 billion. What do you think of his plans for the platform?
content: On Monday, the entrepreneur Elon Musk struck a deal to buy Twitter for $44 billion. The Times reports:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Bob Baffert Could Be Barred From New York Tracks for Two Years
description: A hearing officer recommended the penalty be issued after regulators in three states found him guilty of violating drug regulations.
content: The horse trainer Bob Baffert should be barred from New York State racetracks for two years for conduct detrimental to thoroughbred racing, according to a recommendation issued Wednesday by a hearing officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Often Kept Undercover
description: Alex Bajcz is a crossword wizard.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Alex Bajcz, who is making his seventh appearance in the New York Times Crossword today!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: A Boxer at Auschwitz and the Pain He Carried
description: Ordered to win fights or be put to death, Harry Haft, the subject of a new film, was haunted by the fates of his opponents.
content: Among the lesser-known atrocities perpetrated by the Nazis during World War II were boxing matches that forced emaciated Jewish inmates to fight each other to the death for the entertainment of the German SS officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Kaufman
title: 50 Years of Art in the Bronx
description: The Bronx Museum of the Arts celebrates a major anniversary with plans for expansion that will include a restaurant, a boutique and enhanced public spaces.
content: On a gray morning in March, Klaudio Rodriguez was pacing excitedly through the near-empty galleries of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, which sits amid the southern reaches of the borough’s famed Grand Concourse. The museum’s executive director since late 2020, Mr. Rodriguez was laying out his vision for a Bronx Museum operating at its maximum commercial and cultural potential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: After 31 Years in Prison, a Man Is Freed Over ‘Mistaken Identification’
description: Prosecutors said Thomas Raynard James had the same name as a suspect, leading to his wrongful conviction for murder in 1991. His conviction was overturned.
content: Prosecutors said it appeared to be a “chance coincidence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: How ‘Under the Banner of Heaven’ Took On Murder and the Mormon Church
description: A new FX mini-series adapts the investigative book by Jon Krakauer. He and the creator, Dustin Lance Black, talked about their efforts to get at the truth.
content: Dustin Lance Black still gets emotional when he talks about the time he left the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, around three decades ago. It was hard, he said, because he loved the church. But his Mormon father had run off to marry his own first cousin, leaving behind a wife and three children. And when his stepfather became physically violent, local church leaders circled the wagons and told his mother, who was paralyzed from polio, to leave the police out of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Can Art Help Save the Insect World?
description: A renowned photographer who hopes to persuade humans to love their insect brethren has teamed with scientists on a new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History.
content: For most people, insects are an annoyance — sometimes, a frightening one. They are creatures to be smacked off an arm, stomped with a foot or, in the extreme, obliterated with pesticides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Judge refuses to strike down Elon Musk’s settlement with the S.E.C. over his Twitter posts.
description: Mr. Musk had challenged an agreement he reached with securities regulators after he claimed that he had the funding to take Tesla private.
content: Elon Musk could soon own Twitter, but his own use of the platform will remain constrained by a 2018 agreement he signed with securities regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Americans’ support for admitting refugees is at a record high, Gallup finds.
description: Gallup reported the record high after its new poll found that 78 percent of adults in the United States approve of allowing up to 100,000 Ukrainian refugees into the country.
content: The American public’s support for admitting Ukrainian refugees is higher than Gallup has found in any refugee situation since 1939, the firm said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang, Paul Mozur and Isabelle Qian
title: China’s Covid Lockdown Outrage Tests Limits of Triumphant Propaganda
description: Public anger and grief over the bungled lockdown in Shanghai is creating a credibility crisis for the country’s leader, Xi Jinping, and his zero Covid policies.
content: Immediately after Beijing said it had detected a new coronavirus outbreak, officials hurried to assure residents there was no reason to panic. Food was plentiful, they said, and any lockdown measures would be smooth. But Evelyn Zheng, a freelance writer in the city, was not taking any chances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Meta, Facebook’s parent, reports a 21 percent drop in profits.
description: It was the company’s second consecutive quarterly decline, the first time that had happened in over a decade.
content: Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, has staked his company’s future on an immersive online world known as the metaverse. On Wednesday, the company showed it was still navigating that transformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Levere
title: A Favorite Son Steps Front and Center in Chicago
description: A retrospective, performance piece and projected video, all by Nick Cave, will be on display.
content: For fans of Nick Cave, Chicago is the place to be this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: One month after Amazon takeover, two top MGM executives announce their departures.
description: Michael De Luca and Pamela Abdy, brought on to ready MGM for a sale, announced their departures one month after its acquisition by Amazon.
content: The two top executives at Metro Goldwyn Mayer — Michael De Luca and Pamela Abdy — announced their impending departures on Wednesday, one month after Amazon closed its $8.5 billion acquisition of the film studio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Revisiting a Groundbreaking Show of Feminist Art
description: The Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum looks back at a 1971 exhibition devoted to women and puts their work in conversation with emerging feminist artists.
content: When “Twenty Six Contemporary Women Artists” opened in 1971 at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn., it was the first exhibition of its kind in this country, organized by the feminist art critic Lucy R. Lippard as a direct response to the vast underrepresentation of female artists in museums and galleries. It spawned a wave of similar all-women shows throughout the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Did Faulty Assumptions Dash Parents’ Hope for an Under-5 Vaccine?
description: The under-5 Covid vaccine should be approved.
content: Seventeen months after a Covid vaccine was first authorized for American adults, parents are still waiting for the government to authorize one for children under 5. Some frustrations and setbacks may have been unavoidable, but some seems due to officials making unjustified assumptions about the public and relying on overly narrow and even outdated measures of vaccine benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Farberman
title: The Brazilian Jazz Great Flora Purim Has Many Stories to Tell
description: The musician, now 80, looks back at her time with Chick Corea and Carlos Santana as she prepares to release her first album in 17 years.
content: Once, at a Miles Davis concert, Flora Purim was sitting alone. Janis Joplin took the seat next to her, and a friendship was born. Upon moving to New Jersey, Purim discovered that she was neighbors with João Gilberto. He invited her over, and beat her at Ping-Pong. In 1965, at the João Sebastião Bar in São Paulo, Brazil, Purim was installed as the singer with a band called Sambalanço Trio; on drums was her future partner, Airto Moreira. Chance, one could say, has played an outsize role in her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Former U.S. Ambassador to Plead Guilty to Illegal Lobbying and Hiding Gifts
description: Richard Olson lobbied for the government of Qatar soon after retiring and took gifts from a businessman while serving as ambassador to Pakistan, according to prosecutors.
content: WASHINGTON — Richard G. Olson, a retired diplomat who recently served as ambassador to Pakistan and the United Arab Emirates, said he would plead guilty to charges of illegally lobbying for the government of Qatar and failure to disclose gifts he received while he was an ambassador, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Backs Trump’s Returning to Twitter for One Reason Only
description: Noah joked that he just “really wants to see” the former president’s Wordle scores.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: In ‘The Last Days of Roger Federer,’ Geoff Dyer Ponders the Twilight
description: Dyer’s new book is about last games, last performances and last works — with plenty of detours through other subjects.
content: Geoff Dyer has spent a lifetime writing books that shouldn’t work. A biography of D.H. Lawrence that revolved around his inability to write it. A book about photography, though he didn’t own a camera. When a grumpy music librarian asked him what, exactly, were his credentials for writing a book about jazz, Dyer replied that he had only one: “I like listening to it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Klam
title: Henry Winkler Breaks the Curse of Stardom
description: Now in his 70s, the pop culture icon has found his true calling on “Barry,” as the king of character actors.
content: When the producers of the HBO series “Barry” asked Henry Winkler to audition for the role of Gene Cousineau, they assured him that he was on a short list. Winkler said he was willing, as long as the list didn’t include Dustin Hoffman. “Because he’s a movie star. He’d get it. If Dustin was on the list, I wasn’t going in. They said no. I said OK.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Three Opinion Writers on Why the G.O.P. Can’t Stop Saying ‘Gay’
description: A left-right debate on the overblown gender panic gripping American politics.
content: Florida’s “Don’t Say Gay” bill, states barring transgender athletes from participating in sports and censoring school curriculums around queer and gender identity — a wave of anti-L.G.B.T.Q. legislation is spreading across the country, sustained in large part by the political right. According to the Human Rights Campaign, this year alone, more than 300 anti-L.G.B.T.Q. bills have been introduced in state legislatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eilene Zimmerman
title: Dragons, Saints and a Sexy Nurse: The Art of Takashi Murakami
description: A show at the Broad explores an artist’s efforts to confront the ills of society, and his own anxiety.
content: The centerpiece of the Takashi Murakami exhibition opening in May at the Broad in Los Angeles is a painting so large that, until now, the museum had never displayed it on one wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: Biden’s student loan dilemma
description: The president made a campaign promise to erase billions in college loans, but his economic advisers are split on whether he should follow through.
content: This month, President Biden extended the pandemic pause on federal student loan payments until Aug. 31. But with midterm elections approaching, there is pressure from borrowers and the progressive wing of the Democratic Party to get the president to make good on his campaign promise to cancel up to $10,000 in federal student loans for the roughly 45 million Americans who have those debts, The Times’s Stacy Cowley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: magnum opus
description: This term has appeared in 35 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word magnum opus has appeared in 35 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 24 in “The Score of Final Fantasy Gets Its Due at the Concert Hall” by Aina J. Khan:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Truth Social Review: Trump’s Uncensored Social App Is Incomplete
description: The Trump-backed social media app is inundated with phony accounts and features that don’t work. It also hides some posts, including those with curse words.
content: When Elon Musk sealed a deal to buy Twitter for $44 billion this week, another social networking product surged to No. 1 in Apple’s App Store: Truth Social, the flagship app of former President Donald J. Trump’s fledgling social media company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker, Steve Eder and Julie Tate
title: The Driver, the Officer and the Deadly Traffic Stop in Grand Rapids
description: Patrick Lyoya’s path begins in central Africa, Christopher Schurr’s in Michigan. They cross on a rainy spring morning, in an encounter over a license plate. One ends with a bullet.
content: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Patrick Lyoya never quite found his footing. His family fled conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and he spent nearly half his life in a refugee camp in Malawi. He dreamed of coming to America, but after arriving here, he struggled to find his place, bouncing among homes, low-wage jobs and jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: Coming Soon to the Guggenheim: Words, Words, Words
description: The Manhattan museum’s first poet in residence plans to fill the space with “poem signs,” panels, interactive experiences and pop-up readings.
content: If you visit the Guggenheim Museum this summer, don’t be surprised if some of the works you see are not paintings, sculptures, videos or any other expected forms of visual art. Starting in June, its Manhattan building will bloom with poetry, destined to sprout in places you would hardly consider lyrical: stairwells, the rotunda seating area, the columns in the cafe and eventually even the sidewalk outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Before Washington’s ‘Nerd Prom,’ Lots of Risk-Benefit Calculation
description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci will not attend the White House Correspondents’ Association Dinner, but President Biden has concluded it is worth the risk.
content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Kamala Harris’s coronavirus infection is raising questions that some in the nation’s capital wish would remain unspoken: Is it safe for President Biden to attend the so-called nerd prom, otherwise known as the White House Correspondents’ Dinner? Should the dinner even be held?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Dean Baquet Will Lead Local Investigative Fellowship Program for The Times
description: After he steps down as executive editor, he’ll head an effort to cultivate watchdog reporting to help counter a “crisis in local news.”
content: Dean Baquet, who got his start in journalism at local newspapers and made his name as an investigative reporter, will lead a new local investigative journalism fellowship program at The New York Times when he steps down in June after eight years as the newspaper’s executive editor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Machine Gun Kelly’s Pop-Punk Pivot
description: After decreasing returns in the hip-hop world, the musician and actor stepped into a revival that had roots in SoundCloud rap, and a champion in Travis Barker.
content: One of the most unlikely pop music twists of the last couple of years has been the ascent of Machine Gun Kelly, who recently released “Mainstream Sellout,” his second consecutive No. 1 pop-punk album following a career of decreasing returns in the hip-hop world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Neil MacFarquhar, Shashank Bengali and Megan Specia
title: Ukraine War Impact Widens: Russia Cuts Gas Flow and Vows More Reprisals
description: New explosions across Ukraine’s borders, Russia’s shut-off of natural gas to two European nations and Moscow’s warning of additional “counterstrikes” pointed to escalating hostilities.
content: BRUSSELS — Reverberations from the Ukraine war widened on Wednesday, jolting energy markets and spilling across borders, as Russia responded to the West’s escalating arms shipments and economic penalties by halting gas supplies to two European nations and threatening further unspecified retaliation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and David E. Sanger
title: Russia Uses Cyberattacks in Ukraine to Support Military Strikes, Report Finds
description: A new study by Microsoft shows that Russian cyberattacks often happened within days or even hours of missile strikes.
content: WASHINGTON — For weeks after the outbreak of the war in Ukraine, American officials wondered about the weapon that seemed to be missing: Russia’s mighty cyberarsenal, which most experts expected would be used in the opening hours of an invasion to bring down Ukraine’s power grid, fry its cellphone system and cut off President Volodymyr Zelensky from the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats Lose Control of N.Y. Election Maps, as Top Court Rejects Appeal
description: The Court of Appeals said Democrats violated the State Constitution and ignored the will of the voters. The judges ordered a court-appointed expert to draw replacements.
content: New York’s highest court ruled on Wednesday that Democratic leaders had violated the State Constitution when they took it upon themselves to draw new congressional and State Senate districts, and ordered that a court-appointed special master draft replacement lines for this year’s critical midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: Rings Fit for All Fingers
description: Jewelry designers are listening to a growing community of customers who want larger-size options.
content: Diane Humphreys can palm a volleyball with one hand. She can palm a basketball, too. What Ms. Humphreys cannot do, however, is find rings that fit her size 10.5 to 11 fingers. Apart from her high school volleyball state championship ring — the one custom-ordered from the men’s section because women’s bands were too small — the Atlanta-based director of leadership development has never been much of a ring wearer, though she’d like to be. Ms. Humphreys, 29, has been on the hunt for “something simple” and casual, that she can wear every day. And while it shouldn’t be too much to ask, she’d like it in her size.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Jeffrey E. Singer
title: Reeling From Anti-Asian Attacks, Chinatown Fights City’s Shelter Plan
description: Residents unsettled by recent violence worry that two new shelters, one that would open near the site of a brutal murder, will lead to more disorder.
content: Two new homeless shelters that the city is planning in Lower Manhattan will offer private rooms, health care and drug counseling. They will do away with curfews and many other restrictions as a way to coax homeless people off the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Museums Change Their Approach to Showing White Male Artists
description: In the wake of the Black Lives Matter movement, business-as-usual gets a rethink.
content: Winslow Homer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Jasper Johns and Edward Hopper at the Whitney. Matisse at the Museum of Modern Art and at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Can Japan Keep the Lights On? The Ukraine War Upends a Big Energy Bet.
description: The world’s third-largest economy has counted on imported liquefied natural gas as it shuts coal-fired plants and keeps nuclear sites closed. But Russia’s invasion has pushed prices sharply higher.
content: TOKYO — In 2018, when the power company Hope Energy entered Japan’s new retail electricity market, it thought it had a surefire strategy. Wholesale energy was becoming ever cheaper as liquefied natural gas flooded global markets. Hope Energy would sell competitively priced electricity contracts to local governments and public facilities, undercutting Japan’s old-line power companies, which had long prioritized stable supplies over cost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Carla Morrison Wasn’t Afraid to Go Pop. It Helped Conquer Her Anxiety.
description: With her first album in five years, the Mexican songwriter embraces a new sound, and sings bluntly about her struggles.
content: The Mexican songwriter Carla Morrison had a thriving career in 2017. With her pure soprano, her unabashedly vulnerable songs and constant touring, she had steadily built an audience among Spanish-speaking listeners across the Americas and Europe. Her songs had won Latin Grammy Awards and her first two full-length albums, “Déjenme Llorar” (2012) and “Amor Supremo” (2015), were nominated for Grammys. Morrison was on the road, performing at theaters and festivals following the release of “Amor Supremo Desnudo,” an album of radically altered acoustic remakes of the songs from “Amor Supremo.” Concertgoers were singing along with every word. And she was miserable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: How to Make Miscarriage More Traumatic
description: Anti-abortion laws that don’t prioritize women’s health.
content: In December, I wrote a newsletter with the headline, “Overturning Roe Will Make Miscarriage Care Worse.” I pointed out that because the options that doctors have to end a miscarriage that doesn’t happen on its own — medication or surgery — are the same ones involved in an abortion, outlawing abortion would have a chilling effect on medical providers, as evidenced by cases in countries such as Malta and Poland where abortion is severely restricted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geraldine Fabrikant
title: In Florida, It’s ‘Go West’ for Arts Donors and Patrons
description: Though the state’s east coast museums have long grabbed headlines, transplants from across the U.S., and their money, are also having an impact on its Gulf Coast.
content: The Tampa Museum of Art on Florida’s west coast has raised $71 million toward a $100 million capital campaign to expand its footprint along the city’s Riverwalk, which follows the Hillsborough River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Forsythe, Walt Bogdanich and Chris Hamby
title: Lawmakers Dismiss McKinsey’s Apology on Opioid Crisis as ‘Empty’
description: The consulting firm’s top executive was apologetic before Congress but denied that advising both opioid manufacturers and their federal regulator posed a conflict of interest.
content: The top executive at McKinsey & Company, appearing on Wednesday for the first time before Congress to answer for the consulting firm’s role in fanning the opioid crisis, came under sharp criticism from Democratic lawmakers. One likened the firm’s earnings from advising Purdue Pharma and other pharmaceutical companies to “blood money” from drug traffickers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford lost $3.1 billion in the first quarter.
description: The automaker was hurt by a sharp drop in the value of its holding in Rivian and by a global chip shortage that has limited production.
content: Ford Motor said on Wednesday that it lost $3.1 billion in the first three months of the year because of a sharp drop in the stock price of Rivian, an electric vehicle start-up that Ford has taken a stake in. Ford was also hurt by slowing sales stemming from an ongoing shortage of computer chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: 18 Recipes You Should Learn by Heart
description: Memorize these easy dishes and techniques, and you’ll have an arsenal of easy meals at hand.
content: Everyone has one or two — or 20! — recipes that they know by heart. Perhaps, at first, you referred to the instructions every time you made it, but at some point, you memorized the measurements, how it should look and exactly how it should taste when it’s done. Eventually, it became a standby, your Old Faithful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Cable Giants Comcast and Charter Team Up on Streaming Devices
description: Charter will distribute TV streaming devices based on Comcast’s technology as both try to stay competitive with companies like Roku and Amazon.
content: Comcast and Charter Communications, two of America’s largest cable companies, said on Wednesday that they would team up to offer customers set-top boxes for video streaming, using their combined reach to better compete with established players like Roku and Amazon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Minneapolis Officers Found to Engage in Racist Policing
description: Minnesota’s Department of Human Rights found instances of shockingly racist and misogynistic language, as well as patterns of discrimination in arrests and use of force.
content: The Minneapolis Police Department routinely engages in several forms of racially discriminatory policing, fails to hold officers accountable for misconduct and has used fake social media accounts to target Black people and organizations, according to a damning investigation released on Wednesday by the state’s Department of Human Rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: House Passes Bill Urging Biden to Sell Seized Russian Yachts to Aid Ukraine
description: The measure is mostly symbolic, but the top Senate Democrat is pressing to use a coming Ukraine aid spending bill to give the president the power to liquidate the confiscated property.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday overwhelmingly passed a mostly symbolic bill urging President Biden to sell the frozen luxury assets of Russian oligarchs hit with sanctions and use the funds to provide additional military and humanitarian aid to Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Support from the international community for Ukraine.
content: The U.S. has marshaled 40 allies to furnish Ukraine with long-term military aid in what could become a protracted battle against the Russian invasion. Defense officials from Australia, Belgium, Britain, Italy, Israel and other countries will meet monthly to ensure they “strengthen Ukraine’s military for the long haul,” said Lloyd Austin, the U.S. defense secretary. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italy’s Highest Court Rules Children to Be Given Mother’s and Father’s Surnames
description: The ruling overturns decades of patriarchal family legacy, which largely left women out of the decision-making process.
content: Italy’s top court ruled on Wednesday that children born in the country will be given their mother’s and father’s surnames at birth, declaring the automatic practice of only giving children their father’s surname “constitutionally illegitimate.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: A Long Way Home for ‘Looted’ Art Is Getting Shorter
description: Curators at major museums are increasingly grappling with a thorny topic: restitution.
content: BOSTON — At a time when so-called looted works of art and how to return them to their rightful owners has become a major challenge for museums, Victoria Reed’s role at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston could not be more crucial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Flooded Their Own Village, and Kept the Russians at Bay
description: The waters that poured into Demydiv were one of many instances of Ukraine wreaking havoc on its own territory to slow Russia’s advance. Residents couldn’t be happier. “We saved Kyiv,” one said.
content: DEMYDIV, Ukraine — They pull up soggy linoleum from their floors, and fish potatoes and jars of pickles from submerged cellars. They hang out waterlogged rugs to dry in the pale spring sunshine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Beijing has 138 coronavirus cases. It musters 139,000 workers to test residents.
description: Residents of the Chinese capital face mandatory P.C.R. tests but no mass lockdown yet, while large inland cities may be closed down in response to as few as two infections.
content: BEIJING — Shanghai appeared on Wednesday to be making gradual progress in bringing coronavirus outbreaks under control, while Beijing continued finding more cases as it tries to test three times over five days nearly all of the capital’s 22 million residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Does the Right Do When Big Business Turns Against Republicans?
description: How conservatives put their hope in Elon Musk and Ron DeSantis.
content: Back in 2011, when Elizabeth Warren was preparing to run for the U.S. Senate, she had a long riff making the case against a certain kind of idealized Ayn-Randian vision of the lonely heroic capitalist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Which Animal Viruses Could Infect People? Computers Are Racing to Find Out.
description: Machine learning is known for its ability to spot fraudulent credit charges or recognize faces. Now researchers are siccing the technology on viruses.
content: Colin Carlson, a biologist at Georgetown University, has started to worry about mousepox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: The Energy War Intensifies
description: Russia cuts gas exports to Poland and Bulgaria.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Hanging Out
description: Where do you tend to spend time with your friends? Do you sometimes wish there were more places to go?
content: What do you like to do with your friends? Where do you tend to hang out? Do you sometimes wish there were more places to go?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Cosmic Stories: Du Yun Revisits Her Earliest Music Theater
description: A program at NYU Skirball pairs “Zolle” and “A Cockroach’s Tarantella,” youthful works from when the composer felt “like a fish out of water.”
content: When the composer Du Yun was a doctoral student at Harvard in the early 2000s, she felt like a fish out of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph B. Treaster
title: A Forgotten Star of the Pop Era, Back in the Spotlight
description: Marisol, a Warhol contemporary who was one of the most compelling artists in 1960s New York, is getting renewed attention in a Miami exhibition.
content: MIAMI — In the 1960s, when Pop Art was first dazzling America, a sculptor known as Marisol flashed through the New York art scene like a long-arcing shooting star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Making Dance Out of Survival Skills and Reckoning With Grief
description: Live audiences return for a new platform at Danspace Project featuring Mayfield Brooks, Rashaun Mitchell + Silas Riener, Iele Paloumpis and Ogemdi Ude.
content: How does dance persist in trying times?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: No, New Yorkers Aren’t Flocking to New Jersey for Legal Weed
description: Several factors — including a lack of dispensaries off the nearest PATH stations — are likely to keep New Yorkers from streaming across the Hudson for recreational marijuana.
content: Marijuana dispensaries in New Jersey this weekend were bustling with patrons eager to get their hands on cannabis products as legal recreational sales of the drug kicked off across the state. On Friday, one woman outside a dispensary in Maplewood rejoiced out loud that she had “outlived Prohibition!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Numbers Tell Only Part of the Story
description: Statistics have come to favor Thiago, and they did again in Liverpool’s win over Villarreal in the Champions League. But his passing is best measured in how it swung the complexion of the game.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — With no more daring option immediately apparent, Diogo Jota decided to turn around and start again. There were about a dozen minutes remaining, and Liverpool had long ago entered energy-conservation mode. Jürgen Klopp’s team had, in the blink of an eye, established a two-goal lead over Villarreal in the first leg of their Champions League semifinal, and it had no intention of surrendering it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Here’s the Secret Ingredient in Economic Growth
description: Unfortunately, economists may have been looking at it all wrong.
content: The secret ingredient in economic growth is what economists call total factor productivity. You can always increase output by putting more people or more machines to work, but that consumes real resources. Total factor productivity is the growth you get without having to add labor or capital. Think of it as a new blueprint or a smarter business model that puts existing resources to better use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Dreifus
title: Showcasing the Diversity of the South
description: Arising from one man’s collection, the Ogden Museum strives to serve a broad audience while showing that Southern art is not merely regional.
content: NEW ORLEANS — A signature work at a recent exhibit at the Ogden Museum of Southern Art is a photograph of a cellphone showing on its screen the framed image of an antebellum mansion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: 8 Ways to Teach With Short Documentary Films From The Times
description: How to use our weekly Film Club feature to teach close reading and critical thinking skills via an eclectic mix of nonfiction videos.
content: Death metal-singing grandmothers. Gravity-defying dancers on nine-foot stilts. The dangers of “sharenting.” Coming-of-age with autism. What really happened at Stonewall. The whereabouts of smooth-voiced, permed-haired Bob Ross’s vast collection of lost paintings. These are just a few stories and themes we have explored in our weekly Film Club since it began in 2015.

title: Break a Leg but Never Whistle: How Stage Superstitions Live On
description: The return of the Scottish play (that’s “Macbeth” to the rest of you) is a reminder of the idiosyncratic rituals and routines that bring actors comfort.
content: Theaters are superstitious places, sites of myth, ceremony and invocation. And no stage superstition has more adherents than the one shrouding Shakespeare’s Scottish play: Anyone in a theater who speaks the name Macbeth aloud, except when rehearsing or performing the play, risks catastrophe.

title: The European Union says the emergency phase of the pandemic is over.
description: The bloc recommended focusing on vaccination, surveillance and testing in preparation for a possible fall wave. E.U. states can still make their own policies.
content: The European Union said on Wednesday that it was moving out of the emergency phase of the Covid-19 pandemic, while focusing on vaccination, pandemic surveillance and testing in preparation for a possible new pandemic wave in the fall.

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Cynthia Albritton, Rock’s ‘Plaster Caster,’ Dies at 74
description: She gained fame making sculptures of male rockers’ genitals, an attention-getting gimmick that she grew to regard as art and that became part of rock ’n’ roll lore.
content: “Do I have a favorite?” the artist Cynthia Albritton once said of her signature works. “No, I love them all.”

author: By Shivani Vora
title: Taking the Museum Experience Outdoors
description: Cultural institutions, looking for ways to draw visitors, are offering activities on their grounds — and beyond.
content: A full moon backlit the colorful towers at Grounds for Sculpture on a recent evening, as families, small groups and couples strolled through the 42-acre contemporary art museum and sculpture park in Hamilton, N.J. Rounding the park’s guided loop, the visitors — many first timers to the institution outside Trenton — stopped to gawk at each light and sound installation, whipping out cameras and smartphones to take pictures along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Rolando Hinojosa-Smith, Award-Winning Hispanic Novelist, Dies at 93
description: A Texan raised in two cultures in the Rio Grande Valley border county, he wrote 15 novels about the area and became a major figure in Chicano literature.
content: Rolando Hinojosa-Smith, a charismatic, award-winning writer who created a fictional version of the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas, where he was raised by Anglo and Hispanic parents, as the backdrop for 15 novels set in a border land like his own, died on April 19 in Cedar Park, Texas, a suburb of Austin. He was 93.

content: One day in early January 1970, Michael James Brody Jr. stepped off a Pan Am jet at John F. Kennedy Airport and into what would be one of the new decade’s shortest, strangest 15 minutes of fame.

title: How a Smithsonian Museum Stopped Being About the ‘Wealthy, Pale and Male’
description: The National Portrait Gallery is embracing live performance to highlight American stories missing from its halls.
content: WASHINGTON — For centuries, portraits and busts were reserved for capturing images of the elite, leaving a distorted historical record largely limited to “the wealthy, the pale and the male,” said Kim Sajet, the director of the National Portrait Gallery.

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘A Strange Loop’ Review: A Dazzling Ride on a Mental Merry-Go-Round
description: Michael R. Jackson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning meta musical arrives on Broadway with its uproarious dialogue, complex psychology and eclectic score intact.
content: When the homophobic, God-fearing, Tyler Perry-loving mother of Usher, the protagonist of the remarkable musical “A Strange Loop,” describes her son’s art, she uses the word “radical.” She doesn’t mean it as a compliment.

title: Dumont, N.J.: A ‘Modest Town’ Where $500,000 Still Goes a Long Way
description: Many of the home buyers who find their way to this unassuming Bergen County borough are budget-conscious New Yorkers.
content: At the main crossroads in Dumont, in northern New Jersey, stands a sandstone Reformed church dating to the presidency of Thomas Jefferson. Just up Washington Avenue, a Revolution-era homestead survives as the public library. Next to the freight-train tracks is a diner thought to be the oldest in the state.

content: I am tired. Most days, it is not from weeding — not from the same root cause as the sensation at the back of my legs, when I climb the stairs at the end of a too-long session outside. It is deeper, and simply from being in the world, a landscape of invasive, impossible headlines.

content: Graduate students, faculty and alumni from New York University’s Grossman School of Medicine staged a walkout Wednesday to protest a report that the school may soon hire Dr. David Sabatini, a biologist facing allegations of sexual harassment.

title: At Museums, a Mix of Old and New
description: Masters like Cézanne, Matisse and Georgia O’Keeffe are on display across the country, as well as contemporary artists.
content: American museums are making steady efforts to show a large range of media, styles and perspectives. But this spring and summer, the most notable diversity may be temporal: Some of the greats of the past — like Henri Matisse, Paul Cézanne and Georgia O’Keeffe — are being seen at the same time as contemporary makers now establishing their names, like Shahzia Sikander, Gio Swaby and Guo Pei.

author: By Alex Hutchinson
title: At a Wilderness Resort in Canada, Getting There Is the Only Hard Part
description: No roads lead to Shadow Lake Lodge, in the backcountry near Banff, and reaching it requires an eight-mile hike. The payoff: solitude, adventure and ease.
content: From our lunch spot atop Ball Pass, a windswept notch in the Rocky Mountains that straddles the border between the Canadian provinces of Alberta and British Columbia, we could see our destination in the distance. A sinuous, densely forested valley unfurled below us, flanked by glacier-clad peaks, leading to the tiny turquoise dot of Shadow Lake.

title: Photos of Egyptian Economist Who Died in Custody Raise Questions of Abuse
description: Ayman Hadhoud, a well-known liberal economist and critic of the government, was researching corruption before he disappeared under mysterious circumstances.
content: CAIRO — Ayman Hadhoud, a well-known liberal economist in Egypt, was researching some politically delicate topics like the military’s role in the economy before he disappeared into the custody of the country’s security forces in early February. He had regularly criticized the government and its economic policies on Facebook.

title: Russia Releases Former U.S. Marine in Prisoner Swap
description: Trevor Reed had been detained since 2019, after he was accused of assaulting and endangering the lives of two police officers.
content: WASHINGTON — A plane carrying former Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico and his team landed in Moscow the day before the invasion of Ukraine in February. Their mission: to discuss the possibility of a prisoner swap that could free Trevor R. Reed, an ailing former U.S. Marine held for two years on what his family considered to be bogus charges of assault.

author: By Miguel Morales
title: An Artist Who Makes Use of Housedresses, Resin and Sound
description: From these and other wide-ranging materials, Kevin Beasley creates multilayered works that, even when they’re abstract, have much to say about history and identity.
content: Kevin Beasley begins the tour of his spacious Long Island City studio in the closet. The shelves lining its walls contain two decades’ worth of his work, along with bins of colorful housedresses, a hollowed-out falcon missing its head and several busts that look only vaguely human. “I’m able to carry on this continued relationship,” he says, “rather than reinvent the wheel every time I make something.”

author: By Jake Nevins
title: Sports Betting Has Become So Easy That the Sports Seem Secondary
description: Did a failure to satisfy our diminished attention spans lead to the gamification of every moment of the game?
content: Earlier this year, as I attended my first-ever New York Knicks game, the friendly concessions clerk who handed me my $17 beer before tip-off asked if I’d be placing any bets with FanDuel. The mobile sportsbook app went live in New York just days earlier, after the state became the nation’s 18th to legalize online sports betting. Still, the question surprised me. I wanted to say I was at Madison Square Garden to watch the game, not bet on it — as if this distinction made me some kind of righteous purist. After almost a decade in New York, I had adopted the lowly Knicks as my own, hoping to establish with them an allegiance as devout and excruciating as the one I’d had with my hometown teams in Baltimore. This seemed to me to be the most dignified form of fandom, a birthright uncorrupted by capital, or by the fact of winning or losing at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: How to Cook Scallops and Bacon — But Not Wrapped
description: Scallops seared in bacon fat deliver when the classic hors d’oeuvre falls short.
content: Good morning. Bacon-wrapped scallops are, a trip to Boston reminded me recently, far better in theory than in practice. You see them lined up on platters at Faneuil Hall, passed around at glittery parties in Cambridge, on menus at luxe restaurants and raucous sports bars alike. The flavors marry exquisitely, but it’s almost impossible for anyone to finish cooking both ingredients at the same time, so the result is too often crisp-gummy, unpalatable, grim. Order them at your peril.
